February 1965

October 1965

The linguistics department decides to delay the TK of the major due to short staff.

Between 1965 and 1971, four faculty depart from the Graduate School for Arts and Sciences’ linguistics department.

February 1971

November 12, 1971

An inter-faculty committee on linguistics is formed to evaluate the future of the GSAS linguistics department.

February 1972

The inter-faculty committee’s suggestions are approved by the GSAS Dean. Among them was a significant reduction in the GSAS department’s funding in the face of a University budget crisis. Following an evaluation of the GSAS linguistics department.

1981

Columbia College eliminates its linguistics department.

1983

The major is discontinued. Barnard is the only school with a program now.

October 1984

Citing “limited resources,” Barnard's Faculty Planning Committee (FPC), a group of faculty members charged with studying the college’s academic affairs, eliminates one of the tenure track positions, Robert May. He will leave soon because he’s not allowed to stay after his seventh year.

February 1985

There is a proposal to disband Barnard's Department of Linguistics.

“The fate of [Barnard’s] linguistics department will affect more than just Barnard.”

Barnard teaches four of the eight required courses for an advanced degree from the Graduate School for Arts and Sciences (GSAS). The department also runs a joint BA/MA program with Teachers College.

February 28, 1986

Regarding the FPC’s elimination of May’s role, Spectator writes in a staff editorial,

In an effort to save the sum of an assistant professor's salary and a few office-support costs, the school has undermined its academic and intellectual integrity.
